reviewText: This one is my favorite Starrcade with Starrcade '85 a close second! This was during WCW's era as the NWA, back when there wasn't as much soap opera elements. It was just wrestling! Here is the card:The Fantastics (Tommy Rogers/Bobby Fulton) VS. "Dr. Death" Steve Williams/Kevin Sullivan (NWA U.S. Tag Team Title Match) - This was a good opener. The Fantastics were the champions but you wouldn't know it by watching this match as the team of Sullivan and "Dr. Death" pratically dominated the matchup with a mix of wrestling and brawling! Ends when Williams gives Fulton a "stun gun" as Fulton was going for a Lou Thez Press! New U.S. tag champs.The Midnight Express w/Jim Cornette Vs. The "Original" Midnight Express w/Paul E. Dangerously - Cornette's team of "Sweet" Stan Lane and "Beautiful" Bobby Eaton took on Eaton's former partner "Loverboy" Dennis Condrey and "Ravishing" Randy Rose in one of the best tag team matches in history and should be on anyone's "Best Of" concerning tag team wrestling.Anyway, it was a classic match with interference from both Cornette and Dangerously and textbook double team moves from both sides! Ends when Lane gets the pin on Rose after the "double gozzle" (clothesline/schoolboy trip). The "Original" Midnights got their revenge though as they brutalized MX and Cornette with Jim's own tennis racket and Paul E.'s telephone!Ivan Koloff/Junkyard Dog (RIP) Vs. The Russian Assassins w/Paul Jones - One stipulation of this match was that if the R.A.'s lost, they must unmask and Paul Jones had to retire. The R.A.'s (who were Jack Victory and the late Angel Of Death) were surprisingly dominated by the two veterans. It took a loaded headbutt from one of the "russians" to Ivan Koloff to get the win!Rick Steiner Vs. Mike Rotunda (NWA World TV Title Match) - A 20 minute plus classic! This is when Steiner first came to the national stage against the more experienced Rotunda! Some classic wrestling and very stiff hits in this one. Ends when Kevin Sullivan's plan to interfere backfires, allowing Steiner to get a quick pin and dethrone Rotunda for his first legitimate singles championship!Bam Bam Bigelow w/Sir Oliver Humperdink Vs. Barry Windham w/JJ Dillon (NWA United States Championship Match) - THE best I've personally ever seen the late Bam Bam Bigelow! Windham, as usual during that era, was top notch and was second only to Flair not only in status but in actual skill, charisma and ring generalship and he showed it here.Surprisingly, the two managers let their charges go at it as you didn't really hear or see them much here. It was a good call because this was such a great match! Ends when Windham beats Bam Bam back into the ring before the 10 count and he retains the U.S. title.The Road Warriors w/"Precious" Paul Ellering Vs. Dusty Rhodes & Sting (NWA World Tag Team Title Match) - This one was mostly a showcase for Sting and the LOD as Dusty was almost a non-factor in this. The match ends when Ellering breaks up Sting's pin of Road Warrior Animal and get his team DQ'ed."Nature Boy" Ric Flair Vs. Lex Luger (NWA World Title Match) - An added stipulation was that if Flair was DQ'ed, the title would change hands! This was the best I have personally ever seen from Lex Luger and the beginning of his pretty good period from 1988-1991. As for Flair, what else is needed to be said......WHOOOOOOO!LOL! Anyway, this is a classic 30 plus minute match that doesn't get boring at all. It ends when Luger, while attempting his "Human Torture Rack" backbreaker, falls with Flair on top of him due to his injured left leg that Flair had worked on earlier in the match. Flair, with some help from the ropes, wins the match and retains the title!Overall, a great event to look up if you get the chance!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Thanks to WWE Classics On Demand, I relived an old NWA event in the 1988 edition of Starrcade titled "True Gritt". During this time, Lex Luger was #1 contender for Ric Flair's NWA Championship along with a special stipulation to ensure that there would be a decisive winner in this match. Also, NWA Tag Team Champions The Road Warriors had made their heel turn to feud with Dusty Rhodes & Sting while Rick Steiner was hoping to make his own history at their premiere wrestling event.NWA United States Tag Team Champions The Fantastics vs Kevin Sullivan & "Dr. Death" Steve Williams. For those that don't remember, The Fantastics were a very underrated tag team who had quality matches with the Midnight Express & the Rock & Roll Express. This was a great tag team match between these two teams as the Fantastics were quick & agile team while Sullivan used his experience along with Williams being the power of the team to the point where they took advantage of one mistake that one of the Fantastics made to win the titles.The Midnight Express vs The "Original" Midnight Express. This was an angle revolving around Jim Cornette & Paul E. Dangerously as this was supposed to determine who was the rightful group that should have been under the name "Midnight Express". This match delivered on everything that was advertised in which it was great tag team action with both teams using classic tag team strategy in cutting the ring off & waiting for the hot partner to get the tag along with comedy reactions from Cornette & Dangerously that was really hilarious to watch.The Junkyard Dog & Nikita Koloff vs The Russian Assassins. WOW, another tag team match on the card but honestly this was just a filler match that had nothing special or memorable about it.Television Champion Mike Rotunda vs Rick Steiner. The stipulation to this match was that Kevin Sullivan would be suspended above the ring in a steel cage. This match succeeded in what they wanted to do & that was to get Rick Steiner over which unlike most attempts, it actually worked. Rotunda's wrestling style meshed well with Steiner's power offense which resulted in both men putting on a nearly 20 min. performance that went back & forth with the crowd getting heavily into it with a very unique ending that lead to Steiner getting the title in what he considers the most shining moment of his single's career.United States Champion Barry Windham vs Bam Bam Bigelow. The first match involving a member of the Horsemen. This was a very good match as this match not only proves the fact that Bam Bam Bigelow was one of the best big men wrestlers in the history of the business but also that Windham was heavily underrated during the prime of his career. The ending might be considered a jip by fans (nobody pays for countout endings) but these two still put on a good performance here.NWA Tag Team Champions The Road Warriors vs Sting & Dusty Rhodes. This was during the Road Warrior's heel turn which really didn't go over very well as the crowd was split between both teams here. The Road Warriors used their power offense & even targeted Dusty Rhodes' eye while Sting & Dusty held their own in what was a pretty good tag team match but nothing really memorable past that.NWA Champion Ric Flair vs Lex Luger. This match had a unique stipulation in that if Flair got disqualified, he would lose the title. Before I begin, I want to state that said on my Starrcade '89 review in that match was the best Flair/Luger clash but I am proud to say that I stand corrected as this was their best & most competitive match. They put on a 30 min. performance with Luger using his power while Flair looked to take out Luger's leg that really became a factor at the end of the match & again in what was their best match together, enough said.Overall, this was the type of event that made the NWA special in that they gave you the best wrestling that money could buy from start to finish so I highly recommend this Starrcade card.
summary: Tag Team Warfare & Luger's Last Chance

reviewText: Now I will review the final NWA Pay Per View of 1988 & the 1st under Billionaire Ted Turner Starrcade 1988. Which this is another VHS rip. A lot & I mean a lot has happend since The Great American Bash especially behind the scenes. In November 88 Ted Turner bought Jim Crocett Promotios. The company was renamed World Championship Wrestling but still stayed under The NWA name. During this time Head Booker Dusty Rhodes was relived of his duties cause he must of saw Summer Slam 1988 where The Ultimate Warrior beat Honkey Tonk Man quickley & thought it was a brillant idea to have the newly turned face Rick Steiner beat Ric Flair in less than 5 minutes. Flair was like oh he  l  l no Jim Crockett agreed with him & brought in George Scott to book. Arn Andrerson & Tully Blanchard left the promotion in September cause Tully wasn't happy the pay off from The Bash where he & Arn got paid a $1,000 each & JJ Dillion got only $3,000. Also they had interviews with with the roster when Turner was trying to buy the company he was told by Crockett to be honest well he was verbally ownded on the phone by Crockett. Then when Tully was in Houston he wasn't on the booking sheet & he was no longer on the  plane. The next day he as well as Arn Anderson gave their notice & left. Tully told JJ that this is an end of an era. I honestly agree I did like some of the groups of Horsemen but they can't compare to the 88 group cause the 88 4 Horsemen is my favorite. I was taking what was said by Tully from The Ric Flair & The 4 Horsemen Documentry. Also Ric Flair said on the documentry that The Turner people couldn't have even bought the company with out him. Leave a comment if you want me to review that documentry Ric Flair & The 4 Horsemen. So there was a Clash Of Champions III & IV which Paul  Jones kciked Ivan Koloff out of the group after he lost to Ricky Morton. A new Masked Assassin came in to join Paul Jones group. Arn Anderson & Tully Blanchard dropped The NWA World Tag Team titles to The Midnight Express on September the 10th 1988. Then at a live event on October 29th Hawk & Animal won The NWA World Tag Team Championship then they turned heel. For anyone that cares The Powers Of Pain left The NWA Then a couple of weeks later they attacked Dusty Rhodes 1 of The Road Warriors took a spike from there shoulder pads & attempted to gouge Dusty's eye out. Which was another reason Dusty was let go as The Head Booker. Paul Heyman aka Paul E Dangerously came in with The Original Midnight Express Dennis Condrey & Randy Rose & they quickly fued with Jim Cornette's Midnight Express which they tuned face during their fued with Anderson & Blanchard. Also at The Clash Of Champions IV Seasons Beatings Ric Flair & Barry Windham cheated to beat Eaton & Lane. Cornette cut a really good promo at the end of the show as well. The Fantastics won The NWA US Tag Team Championship when they beat Ron Simmons & Eddie Gillbert in a finals match in a tournament cause they were vacated by The Midnuight Express when they won The World Tag Team titles Cornette & The Express went through a lot since The GAB. Rick Steiner left The Varsity Club & GOT himself a shot at Mike Rotundo's NWA Television Championship. Flair & Luger continued to fued over the World title which originally it was decided that Luger was going to win The NWA World Heavyweight Championship. When Dusty was removed as booker it was changed to Flair beating Luger cleanly then Flair changed it with him going over dirty with his feet on the ropes. Also a stipulation was added if Flair got himself disqulified he would lose The NWA World Championship. Bam Bam Bigelow came in & got a shot for Barry Windham's US title. Dr Death Steve Williams joined The Varsity Club. So I hope I covered everything the buyrate was a 1.80Attendance10,000VenueNorfolk ScopeCityNorfolk, VirginiaNWA United States Tag Team ChampionshipThe Varsity Club Kevin Sullivan & Dr Death Steve Williams Def Champpions The Fantastics Bobby Fulton & Tommy Rodgers **to win the titlesJim Cornette's Midnight Express Bobby Eaton & Stan Lane Def The Original Midnigh Express Randy Rose & Dennis Condrey with Paul E Dangerouly.*** Good tag team war where Cornette & Heyman were used well. Heyman's Original Express beat Cornette up after the match Eaton made the save.The Russian Assassins with Paul Jones Def The Junkyard Dog & Ivan Koloff * & half starOk so it was suppose to be Nikita & Ivan Koloff I don't know what was going on around this time I think Nikita's wife died. If JYD & Koloff won Paul Jones would've had to retire & The Russian Assassins would've had to unmask.NWA World Television ChampionshipRick Steiner Def Champion Mike Rotundo Kevin Sullivan was in a cage above the ring. * & a quarter starSteiner got a huge pop when he won ending the 11 month reign of Mike Rotundo. Unfortantly this was an edited match so I can't give it a good rating.NWA United States ChampionshipChampion Barry Windham with James J Dillion &Bam; Bam Bigelow with Sir Oliver Humperdink wrestled to  a count out *** Bigelow was counted out. Bigelow did a good job I guess this was early on in his career & Winham used some of Flair's tricks.NWA World Tag Team ChampionshipChampions The Road Warriors Hawk & Animal with Paul Ellering vs Sting & Dusty Rhodes  ** & a quarter stars. The Road Warriors were disqualified but they retainded the titles.NWA World Heavyweight ChampionshipChampion Ric Flair with James J Dillion Def Lex Luger **** & 3 of a quarter stars.The stipulation was added if Ric Flair got himself disqualified he'd lose The NWA World Championship. Luger back then could have good matches if he had the right opponet around this time 88, 89, 90 & 91 was to me when he was at his best when  he came back in 1995 he was never the same. Next will be 1989 which was a great yeat all around. The 1st under The WCW name starting with The Chi Town Rumble.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The NWA/WCW was/is the best league ever. The AWA is close. The WWE is overated. The ECW died way too prematurely. Luger vs. Flair is a classic and that's for starters. All-star collection of matches unparalleled! These guys are Chump Hogan's nightmares come to life!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Event: NWA StarrCade 1988: "True Gritt"Date: December 26, 1988Location: Norfolk, VirginiaArena: The ScopeAttendence: 10,000United States Tag Team Title Match: Kevin Sullivan and Steve Williams defeated The Fantastics (Bobby Fulton and Tommy Rogers) (15:50) when Williams pinned Fulton to win the tag team titles....****The Midnight Express (Bobby Eaton and Stan Lane) defeated The Originial Midnight Express (Dennis Condrey and Randy Rose) (17:46) when Lane pinned Rose....*****The Russian Assassins (#1 and #2) defeated Junkyard Dog and Ivan Koloff (6:47) when Koloff was pinned by Assassin #1....***World Televsion Title Match: Rick Steiner pinned Mike Rotunda (17:59) to win the title....****United States Heavyweight Title Match: Barry Windham defeated Bam Bam Bigelow (16:17) by count out to retain the title....****World Tag Team Title Match: Dusty Rhodes and Sting defeated The Road Warriors (Hawk and Animal) (11:20) by Disqualification. The Road Warriors retain the tag team titles....***(ending with the DQ)World Heavyweight Title Match: Ric Flair pinned Lex Luger (30:59) to retain the title....***** (Amazing Match...A Must see!!)Bunkhouse Stampede Match: Junkyard Dog won a "bunkhouse stampede." Also in the match were: Abdullah the Butcher, Ray Candy, Eddie Gilbert, Junkyard Dog, Dick Murdoch, Dustin Rhodes, Steve Williams, and others. ***
summary: Classic NWA Event! Flair Vs Lugar AMAZING!

reviewerName: Shadow Fire Promotions, Inc. "Your Chicago So...
reviewText: I disagree with my South African colleague about his reasons why the NWA/WCW never caught up to the WWF. I'm not going into the reasons why.  Anyone can read various books and find out the assorted reasons why WCW failed.  My opinion lies strictly in the card.  My colleague states that Luger should have been champion and he would have carried the company.  I disagree.  Luger was heavily pushed due to his physique, and in 1986-7, as a Horseman, he may have been championship ready, but he is clearly not ready for the big time, and like Sting, he failed to be a draw for WCW.  Sure, WCW pushed older guys when they should have focused on their younger crew, but Luger has proven that he lacks the tools to draw as a main eventer.  Sting was mega-popular, but also failed to draw as champion, and Luger was nowhere near as popular.  Luger was pushed for his physique alone, not because of great skill, credibility, or love for this sport.  His first championship reign in late 91-early 92 is proof.  The bottom line is that Flair may have been slowly getting past his prime in 1988(though that is debatable, based on his great 1989 battles with Funk and Steamboat), but at that time, Flair was the only one credible enough to hold the belt.  Always remember that as much as WCW tried to bury Flair, whenever they got into a bind, the belt was always given back to Flair, who being the company man he is, always managed to resuscitate the ailing company he loved.  Storylines aside, I have always loved to watch NWA wrestling because of the match quality, which is present here.  I only wish I owned this great tape.
Title: N/A
